_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: fire sprinkler system, fire extinguishers, forklift, transportation trucks
_prev_prog_2.Description:
As required in 40 CFR Part 68.170, the facility has an active prevention program.  Written protocols and defined employee responsibilities are outlined in a facility specific emergency response plan.  The plan is available to all employees either in written form or by password protected files on the facilityA?s computer network.  Included in the program are quarterly safety newsletters to remind employees of safe practices and to inform employees of any new safety procedures and/or technology.  Selected facility employees maintain appropriate certifications that allow for these employees to mitigate releases on site.  These training sessions include, but are not limited to, proper forklift use, chemical identification, facility security protocols, MSDS location and identification, and various other OSHA job related courses.  These courses are provided to maintain safe handling of facility chemicals and proper use of equipment.  The facility has a monitored fire suppression system which can be utilized to suppress vapors and /or dilute chemicals in the event of a release.  The local fire department conducts yearly fire inspections to ensure the facility meets local building codes and that fire suppression equipment is operable.  Fire department and hazardous material teams receive Tier II documents identify the chemicals the facility stores on site.  Location of these chemicals is identified during regularly scheduled building inspections.  The facility maintains proper NFPS 704 placards on the outside of the building.  Individual chemical containers maintain proper identification placards. 

Facility employees have a hazardous materials communication plan.  The plan outlines both internal and external communication procedures in the event of a release.  Internal communications include the notification of a release to other employees and to facility management.  The internal communication outlines specific responsibilities to each manager of the facility (ie, incident commander, safety officer, etc.)  External communications outlines local, state, and federal agencies with contact numbers that are to be notified of the release.  Included in the prevention plan are various security measures.  These measures ensure no unauthorized individuals can obtain access to the chemicals located at the facility either physically or by cyber attacks.  Additional security measures include daily inventory counts of products located at the facility, use of pre-approved shipping companies, a visitor sign in sheet, and electronic surveillance to mention a few.  All doors and gates remain secured until access is required with the exception being the front office door.  The facility is secured by a ten foot chain link fence with razor wire at the top.  Entry onto the grounds of the facility requires proper shipper and product identification be identified and verified.  Entry into the front office of the facility is made through the facility main door.  A visitor sign in sheet is required of all visitors to register.  Recordable video cameras record activity at the facility. The facility has contracted with a training provider company to ensure employees maintain appropriate certifications and an environmental consultant to ensure applicable state and federal environmental regulations are followed.  Routine site inspections are conducted by both facility management and both consultants to ensure the facility and its employees are working in a safe manner.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: DEA Class II Chemical reporting, FDA food storage/transportation regulations

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Advanced Chemical Logistics (referred to as the facility) is a chemical distribution company located in Richland Hills, Tarrant County, Texas.  The facility is in a light industrial area on the south by south west side of town.  The latitude is 32 47' 46'' and longitude -97 13' 48''.  The facility has an NAICS code of 42269 which identifies it as a chemical distributor and as defined in 40 CFR Part 68.10(b)(2) is a Program 2 facility.  The facility has approximately six to seven employees with as many as four being on the site at any given time.  The city has an approximate population 8,132.  Within one half mile of the facility is a mass transit train station.  This transient population can add an additional 500 to 750 between the hours of 0530 to 0900 hours in the morning and 1600 to 1830 hours in the evening.  The rail line runs approximately 200 yards to the North of the facility.  Highway 121 is approximately 400 yards to the north of the facility and has heavytraffic during rush hour.  To the north and to the north west lies a dense residential area. Industrial businesses are located to the east and to the south east of the facility.  The industrial park is the second largest in Tarrant County.  Day time population of the industrial park can range from 250 to 1,000 employees depending on occupancy and time of day.  During the evening hours these businesses are closed and the population is <10 depending on security guards hired by the independent businesses.
The facility is approximately 22,000 square feet of warehouse storage space.  The property is secured by an n eight foot chain link fence on three of the four sides of the property.  Three toxic chemicals were identified under EPA's CAA 112 (r), 40 CFR Part 68.130 tables 1 and 2. Using 40 CFR Part 68.130 tables 3 and 4, no flammable chemicals as described by the type and/or reportable quantity were identified at the facility.   Concrete floors, concrete dikes and water sprinkler system are utilized to mitig

ate potential chemical releases.  Facility continuing education programs provide employees with, but not limited to, mitigation response roles, chemical identification, evacuation procedures, hazardous release communication system, and facility security.  These efforts ensure that all facility employees will respond in a unified and coordinated response effort in the event of a chemical release.  The facility is within the Richland Hills, TX, fire department (RHFD) jurisdiction.  Additionally, RHFD is a member of an eight city combined hazmat response team.  The hazmat truck and hazmat coordinator are stationed at the North Richland Hills, TX, fire department (NRHFD).  Local response time is <3 minutes.  The unified hazmat response team response time is <8 minutes.  The hazmat team has the equipment and personal training to conduct basic air and water sampling, mitigate active leaks, conduct shelter in place and/or evacuate business and/or residence, and dike, dam, and/or divert the release.  Vapor and/or fire suppression could also be provided by the utilization of a 100 foot aerial ladder with two water nozzles and a 75 foot aerial ladder with a water nozzle.  Additional assistance can be requested from the Environmental Protection Agency Region 6 (EPAR6) located in Dallas, TX, and/or Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Emergency Response Regional Team stationed in Ft. Worth, TX. Regularly scheduled fire department building inspections ensure the facility is in compliance with local fire code requirements.
The facility is inspected yearly by the local fire department for national and local fire code enforcement.  These inspections ensure that fire suppression sprinkler system and fire extinguishers are in proper working order.  Facility emergency exits must be clearly marked and free of clutter and/or debris.  The facility maintains a strong partnership with the local fire department and mutual aid hazmat team.  Facility employees participate in mock

exercises to maintain skills necessary to mitigate and manage any potential releases at the facility.  Employees are also required to participate in a variety of on-line safety training courses to minimize accidents and work related injuries.  Employees participate in yearly reviews of hazards communication program training and site security programs.  These programs address procedures for illegal entry into the facility, notification process in the event of an accidental or man-made release, and basic mitigation procedures for nuisance spills.
The facility utilizes an outside contractor to provide "spot" inspections to ensure regulatory compliance.  The facility is currently utilizing voluntary inspections offered by Department of Homeland Security and OSHA to ensure regulatory compliance.  Compliance issues are brought to the attention of the facility manager and addressed in a timely manner.  Regulatory guidance is also provided to the facility in matters of regulatory reporting, waste management, and any potential training that would better prepare employees for an emergency response.  The facility voluntarily provides reporting documents to the EPA, TCEQ, DEA, and DHS.  The facility is also a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and currently complies with NACD's recommendations of good chemical stewardship.
